courseIdentity.title: Software Requirements Engineering
courseIdentity.catalogDescription: This course explores the critical process of gathering, analyzing, and documenting software requirements. Students learn to elicit stakeholder needs, create specifications, and manage requirements throughout the software development lifecycle.

courseLearningOutcomes.description: Elicit and document software requirements from diverse stakeholders
Create comprehensive requirement specifications using industry-standard formats
Manage requirements changes and traceability throughout project lifecycle
Validate and verify requirements for completeness and consistency

programLearningOutcomes.description: Design and implement software solutions using appropriate methodologies
Apply critical thinking to solve complex technical problems
Communicate technical concepts effectively to diverse audiences

topicalOutline.body:
Week 1-2: Introduction to Requirements Engineering
Week 3-4: Stakeholder Analysis and Elicitation Techniques
Week 5-6: Requirements Documentation and Specification
Week 7-8: Requirements Modeling and Analysis
Week 9-10: Requirements Validation and Verification
Week 11-12: Requirements Management and Traceability
Week 13-14: Agile Requirements and User Stories
Week 15: Final Project Presentations

majorAssessments.name: Stakeholder Interview Project
majorAssessments.description: Conduct interviews with real stakeholders to elicit requirements for a software system

majorAssessments.name: Requirements Specification Document
majorAssessments.description: Create a comprehensive SRS document for a proposed software system

majorAssessments.name: Requirements Management System
majorAssessments.description: Implement and demonstrate a requirements traceability matrix and change management process

facilities.body: Computer lab with 25 workstations, projector, and whiteboard

technology.body: Requirements management tools (JIRA, ReqIF), diagramming software (Lucidchart, Draw.io), collaborative documentation platforms

otherResources.body: Access to industry professionals for guest lectures and stakeholder interview practice

courseIdentity.title: Database Design and Implementation
courseIdentity.catalogDescription: An in-depth study of database management systems covering data modeling, normalization, SQL, transaction processing, and database administration. Students design and implement relational databases for real-world applications.

courseLearningOutcomes.description: Design normalized relational database schemas using ER modeling
Write complex SQL queries including joins, subqueries, and aggregations
Implement database security and transaction management
Optimize database performance through indexing and query tuning

programLearningOutcomes.description: Design and implement software solutions using appropriate methodologies
Apply critical thinking to solve complex technical problems
Practice ethical decision-making in technology contexts

topicalOutline.body:
Week 1-2: Introduction to Database Systems
Week 3-4: ER Modeling and Relational Design
Week 5-6: Normalization and Schema Refinement
Week 7-8: SQL Fundamentals and Advanced Queries
Week 9-10: Transaction Management and Concurrency
Week 11-12: Database Security and Authorization
Week 13-14: Performance Optimization and Indexing
Week 15: Final Project Presentations

majorAssessments.name: Database Design Project
majorAssessments.description: Design a complete database schema for a real-world application with ER diagrams and normalization

majorAssessments.name: SQL Mastery Assessment
majorAssessments.description: Demonstrate proficiency in writing complex queries for data analysis

majorAssessments.name: Database Implementation Project
majorAssessments.description: Implement and deploy a full database application with security and optimization

facilities.body: Computer lab with database server access

technology.body: PostgreSQL, MySQL, Oracle DB, database modeling tools (ERDPlus, MySQL Workbench)

otherResources.body: Cloud database hosting for student projects (AWS RDS or Azure SQL)

courseIdentity.title: Web Application Development
courseIdentity.catalogDescription: Comprehensive coverage of modern web development including HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, front-end frameworks, back-end services, and responsive design. Students build full-stack web applications using current industry practices.

courseLearningOutcomes.description: Develop responsive web interfaces using modern HTML5, CSS3, and JavaScript
Implement client-side applications using contemporary frameworks (React, Vue, or Angular)
Create RESTful APIs and back-end services with proper authentication
Deploy and maintain full-stack web applications using cloud platforms

programLearningOutcomes.description: Design and implement software solutions using appropriate methodologies
Practice ethical decision-making in technology contexts
Engage in continuous learning and adapt to evolving technologies

topicalOutline.body:
Week 1-2: Modern Web Architecture and Tooling
Week 3-4: Advanced HTML5 and CSS3 Techniques
Week 5-6: JavaScript ES6+ and Async Programming
Week 7-8: Front-end Framework Fundamentals
Week 9-10: Component-Based Development
Week 11-12: RESTful APIs and Backend Integration
Week 13-14: Authentication, Security, and Deployment
Week 15: Final Project Presentations

majorAssessments.name: Responsive Portfolio Website
majorAssessments.description: Create a fully responsive personal portfolio using modern HTML/CSS/JS

majorAssessments.name: Single Page Application
majorAssessments.description: Build an interactive SPA using a modern framework with state management

majorAssessments.name: Full-Stack Web Application
majorAssessments.description: Develop and deploy a complete web application with frontend, backend, and database

facilities.body: Computer lab with modern development tools and dual monitors

technology.body: Node.js, React/Vue/Angular, VS Code, Git, cloud hosting platforms (Vercel, Netlify, Heroku)

otherResources.body: GitHub education accounts for students, API keys for third-party services

courseIdentity.title: Environmental Science and Sustainability
courseIdentity.catalogDescription: Interdisciplinary study of environmental systems, ecological principles, resource management, and sustainability challenges. Explores the relationship between human activity and environmental impact with focus on solutions.

courseLearningOutcomes.description: Analyze environmental systems using scientific methods and ecological principles
Evaluate sustainability challenges from multiple cultural and economic perspectives
Assess environmental policies and their ethical implications for diverse communities
Propose evidence-based solutions to local and global environmental problems

programLearningOutcomes.description: Apply scientific inquiry to understand natural and human systems
Recognize diverse worldviews and cultural perspectives on environment
Integrate knowledge across disciplines to address complex challenges
Engage in ethical decision-making for sustainable futures

topicalOutline.body:
Week 1-2: Introduction to Environmental Science
Week 3-4: Ecosystem Structure and Function
Week 5-6: Biodiversity and Conservation
Week 7-8: Climate Change Science and Impacts
Week 9-10: Energy Systems and Sustainability
Week 11-12: Environmental Justice and Equity
Week 13-14: Sustainable Solutions and Policy
Week 15: Final Project Presentations

majorAssessments.name: Global Sustainability Analysis
majorAssessments.description: Compare sustainability approaches across different cultural and economic contexts

majorAssessments.name: Environmental Action Project
majorAssessments.description: Develop and present a comprehensive plan for addressing a local environmental challenge

facilities.body: Science lab with field equipment, microscopes, and water quality testing tools

technology.body: GIS software, environmental modeling tools, data analysis software

otherResources.body: Transportation for field trips, guest speakers from environmental organizations

courseIdentity.title: Principles of Management
courseIdentity.catalogDescription: Introduction to management theory and practice covering planning, organizing, leading, and controlling. Explores leadership styles, organizational behavior, decision-making, and ethical considerations in business contexts.

courseLearningOutcomes.description: Apply management theories to organizational scenarios
Evaluate leadership approaches and their effectiveness
Develop strategic plans for organizational challenges
Communicate management decisions effectively to stakeholders

courseIdentity.title: Game Design and Development
courseIdentity.catalogDescription: Explores game design principles, mechanics, narrative, and user experience. Students use industry-standard engines to develop 2D and 3D games, learning programming, asset creation, and iterative design processes.

courseLearningOutcomes.description: Design engaging game mechanics and systems
Implement game prototypes using industry tools
Collaborate in interdisciplinary game development teams
Iterate on game designs based on playtesting feedback

courseIdentity.title: Discrete Mathematics
courseIdentity.catalogDescription: Mathematical foundations for computer science including logic, set theory, functions, relations, combinatorics, graph theory, and proof techniques. Emphasizes problem-solving and mathematical reasoning.

courseLearningOutcomes.description: Apply logical reasoning and proof techniques to mathematical problems
Solve combinatorial and graph theory problems
Analyze algorithms using discrete mathematics concepts
Communicate mathematical ideas clearly and precisely

programLearningOutcomes.description: Demonstrate mathematical reasoning and proof skills
Apply quantitative methods to solve problems
Express mathematical concepts effectively

topicalOutline.body:

Week 3-4: Set Theory and Functions
Week 5-6: Relations and Equivalence
Week 7-8: Combinatorics and Counting
Week 9-10: Graph Theory Fundamentals
Week 11-12: Trees and Networks
Week 13-14: Recurrence Relations
Week 15: Final Exam Review

courseIdentity.catalogDescription: Introduction to programming concepts using Python. Covers variables, data types, control structures, functions, and basic algorithms. No prior programming experience required.

courseIdentity.title: Calculus I
courseIdentity.catalogDescription: Introduction to differential calculus including limits, derivatives, and applications. Covers techniques of differentiation, optimization, and related rates. Foundation for advanced mathematics and sciences.

Calculate derivatives using various techniques
